# **R Markdown Syntax**

### 1. Chunk option with a missleading answer 

```{r computeA}
a = 64
```
```{r computeB, cache = TRUE}
b = sqrt (a)
```

The **square root** of a = b =  `r (b)` (this result is obviously wrong because we had previously set a = 36 and then changed for a = 64. It was **not recalculated** because cache = TRUE for b. To have the right result, we should put cache = FALSE for b)

### 2. Random sample from a uniform distribution (n=100)
```{R, echo = FALSE}
x = runif (100)
```

Simulation of 100 random samples from a Uniform distribution : 

The **mean** is ```r round(mean(x), 4)``` 

The **median** is ```r round(median(x), 4)```

The **variance** is ```r round(var(x), 4)```

• Are these results different from 1/2, 1/2 and 1/12 (their respective theoretical values)? Is this result surprising? Justify your answer

**Answer** : The results do not correspond exactly to 0.5 for the mean, 0.5 for the median and 1/12 for the variance. This is due to the small size of our sample which is n=100. This lack of precision is not surprising. The more we increase the size of this sample, the closer we will get to these values.  


### 3. Histogram of X
```{R, echo=FALSE}
hist(x, main = "Histogram of a random sample from a uniform distribution", ylab = "Frequency", xlab = "X")
```

### 4. Centered equation 

$$
\begin{align*}
 \mathbb{E}\left [\mathrm{var}\left \{\mathbf{v}_{1}\left (\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta }},n \right )\mid \boldsymbol{\hat{\theta }} \right \} \right ] &= \mathrm{var} \left \{ \mathbf{v}_{1} \left ( \boldsymbol{{\theta}}_{0},n \right ) \right \} + \mathbb{E} \left [  \mathcal{O}_{p} \left \{ \left. \mathbf{D}_{1}(\boldsymbol{{\theta^{*} }},n)(\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta }}-\boldsymbol{{\theta}}_{0}),...,\mathbf{D}_{p} (\boldsymbol{{\theta^{*} }},n)(\boldsymbol{{\theta}} -\boldsymbol{{\theta}}_{0}) \right \} \right. \right ]  \\
      &= \mathrm{var} \left \{ \mathbf{v}_{1} \left (\boldsymbol{{\theta}}_{0},n \right ) \right \} +  \mathcal{O}_{p}(n^{-2}).   
\end{align*} $$


### 5. In-line equation 

$$ \boldsymbol{{A}} \equiv \left [ a_{i,j} \right ]_{i,j}= 1,...,p ^ {.}$$
